column1: * Fence helper functions to deal with KFD memory eviction.

* All the BOs in a process share an eviction fence. When process X wants
* to map VRAM memory but TTM can't find enough space
* evict BOs from its LRU list. TTM checks if the BO is valuable to evict
* ttm_device_funcs->eviction_valuable() - will return false if the BO belongs

This reference gets released in amdkfd_fence_release */

column1: * The GART (Graphics Aperture Remapping Table) is an aperture
* in the GPU's address space.  System pages can be mapped into
* the aperture and look like contiguous pages from the GPU's
* perspective.  A page table maps the pages in the aperture
* to the actual backing pages in system memory.
* Radeon GPUs support both an internal GART

column1: * and maintained by the northbridge rather than the driver.

* point to the AGP aperture provided by the northbridge and the
* requests are passed through to the northbridge aperture.
* Both AGP and internal GART can be used at the same time
* that is not currently supported by the driver.
* This file handles the common internal GART management.
* amdgpu_gart_dummy_page_init - init dummy page used by the driver
* Allocate the dummy page used by the driver (all asics).
* This dummy page is used by the driver as a filler for gart entries
* when pages are taken out of the GART
* amdgpu_gart_dummy_page_fini - free dummy page used by the driver
* Frees the dummy page used by the driver (all asics).

* Allocate video memory for GART page table
* gart table to be in video memory.
* amdgpu_gart_table_vram_pin - pin gart page table in vram
* Pin the GART page table in vram so it will not be moved

* Unpin the GART page table in vram (pcie r4xx
* These asics require the gart table to be in video memory.

* Each MEC supports 4 compute pipes and each pipe supports 8 queues.

column1: * - 3.3.0 - Add VM support for UVD on supported hardware.
* - 3.5.0 - Add support for new UVD_NO_OP register.
* - 3.6.0 - kmd involves use CONTEXT_CONTROL in ring buffer.
* - 3.7.0 - Add support for VCE clock list packet
* - 3.8.0 - Add support raster config init in the kernel
* - 3.9.0 - Add support for memory query info about VRAM and GTT.
* - 3.10.0 - Add support for new fences ioctl
* - 3.11.0 - Add support for sensor query info (clocks
* - 3.12.0 - Add query for double offchip LDS buffers
* - 3.14.0 - Fix race in amdgpu_ctx_get_fence() and note new functionality
* - 3.15.0 - Export more gpu info for gfx9
* - 3.18.0 - Export gpu always on cu bitmap
* - 3.19.0 - Add support for UVD MJPEG decode
* - 3.23.0 - Add query for VRAM lost counter
* - 3.24.0 - Add high priority compute support for gfx9
* - 3.25.0 - Add support for sensor query info (stable pstate sclk/mclk).
* - 3.27.0 - Add new chunk to to AMDGPU_CS to enable BO_LIST creation.
* - 3.31.0 - Add support for per-flip tiling attribute changes with DC
* - 3.32.0 - Add syncobj timeline support to AMDGPU_CS.
* - 3.33.0 - Fixes for GDS ENOMEM failures in AMDGPU_CS.
* - 3.34.0 - Non-DC can flip correctly between buffers with different pitches
* - 3.36.0 - Allow reading more status registers on si/cik
* - 3.37.0 - L2 is invalidated before SDMA IBs
* - 3.39.0 - DMABUF implicit sync does a full pipeline sync
* - 3.44.0 - DCN3 supports DCC independent block settings: !64B && 128B

* For coherent userptr handling registers an MMU notifier to inform the driver

* amdgpu_mn_register - register a BO for notifier updates

* Parts of this file were based on the MCDE driver by Marcus Lorentzon
* The MCDE (short for multi-channel display engine) is a graphics
* controller found in the Ux500 chipsets
* It was initially conceptualized by ST Microelectronics for the
* ST-Ericsson U8500 where is was used for mass-market deployments
* in Android phones from Samsung and Sony Ericsson.
* It can do 1080p30 on SDTV CCIR656
* panels with or without frame buffering and can convert most
* input formats including most variants of RGB and YUV.
* The hardware has four display pipes

* If we have a reference clock we can enable communication w/ the
* panel (including the aux channel) w/out any need for an input clock
* so we can do it in resume which lets us read the EDID before
* pre_enable(). Without a reference clock we need the MIPI reference
* clock so reading early doesn't work.
* We might get an error back if debugfs wasn't enabled in the kernel

* AUX bus docs say that a non-NULL release is mandatory
* sense for the model used here where all of the aux devices are allocated
* in the single shared structure. We'll use this noop as a workaround.

* IOMMU support. This can happen for example on Tegra20
* Tegra124 and later can address up to 34 bits of physical memory and
* many platforms come equipped with more than 2 GiB of system memory
* which requires crossing the 4 GiB boundary. But there's a catch: on
* SoCs before Tegra186 (i.e. Tegra124 and Tegra210)
* only address up to 32 bits of memory in GATHER opcodes
* that command buffers need to either be in the first 2 GiB of system
* memory (which could quickly lead to memory exhaustion)
* buffers need to be treated differently from other buffers (which is
* not possible with the current ABI).
* A third option is to use the IOMMU in these cases to make sure all
* buffers will be mapped into a 32-bit IOVA space that host1x can
* address. This allows all of the system memory to be used and works
* within the limitations of the host1x on these SoCs.
